sect2.title: Introduction
sect2.para: If you're not working in a team but working alone on a project and still want your work under version control you can also access a repository locally. This kind of repository access is also very handy if you just want to try out some Subversion commands and you don't want to change your official repository.

sect2.title: Creating The Repository With TortoiseSVN

figure.title: The TortoiseSVN menu for unversioned folders

listitem.para: Create a new folder and name it e.g. SVNRepository

Right-click on the newly created folder and select
TortoiseSVN Create Repository here... .

You can create a repository with the FSFS backend or with the old but stable Berkeley Database (BDB) format. The FSFS format is faster and it now works on network shares and Windows 98 without problems. The BDB format is more stable because it has been tested longer, but can be more difficult to administer. Read
Chapter 5, Repository Data-Stores
in the SVN book for more information.
A repository is then created inside the new folder. Don't edit those files yourself!!!. If you get any errors make sure that the folder is empty and not write protected.

sect2.para: To access your local repository you need the path to that folder. Just remember that Subversion expects all repository paths in the form file:///C:/SVNRepository/

To access a repository located on a network share you can either use drive mapping, or you can use the UNC path. For UNC paths, the form is file:///\ServerName/path/to/repos/. Note the backslash before the server name.

warning.para: Do not create or access a Berkeley DB repository on a network share. It cannot exist on a remote filesystem. Not even if you have the network drive mapped to a drive letter. If you attempt to use Berkeley DB on a network share, the results are unpredictable - you may see mysterious errors right away, or it may be months before you discover that your repository database is subtly corrupted.

tip.para: If you really need to access a repository through a network share, create the repository with fsfs format. If you need to provide server access as well, you will need Subversion Server 1.1 or higher.
